title: 113_hr236
content: The "Crackdown on Deadbeat Gun Dealers Act of 2013" increases compliance inspections of firearms dealers, raises penalties on firearms licensees, addresses serious recordkeeping offenses aiding gun trafficking, and introduces suspension of firearms dealer's license and civil penalties for violations of the Gun Control Act. Subsections (e) and (f) of section 923 of title 18, United States Code, are amended to give the Attorney General the authority to suspend or revoke a license issued under this section, or impose a civil penalty of up to $10,000 per violation for willful violations of gun control laws or failure to provide secure gun storage at the place of sale. The Attorney General has the authority to suspend or revoke a dealer's license or impose a civil penalty of up to $10,000 for willfully transferring armor-piercing ammunition. Any person denied a license or facing suspension, revocation, or civil penalty will receive a written notice stating the grounds for the action. The Attorney General has the authority to suspend, revoke, or impose civil penalties on a dealer's license for transferring armor-piercing ammunition. The aggrieved party can request a hearing to review the denial, suspension, or revocation of a license. The Attorney General must provide written notice of the grounds for any action taken. The Attorney General can suspend, revoke, or impose civil penalties on a dealer's license for transferring armor-piercing ammunition. The aggrieved party can request a hearing to review the decision. If the Attorney General decides not to reverse the decision, the aggrieved party can file a petition for judicial review within 60 days. The court can consider any evidence submitted, even if not presented at the initial hearing. The court can order the Attorney General to comply with its judgment if it decides that the Attorney General was not authorized to deny, suspend, revoke, or assess penalties on a dealer's license for transferring armor-piercing ammunition. SEC. 6 amends Section 925(b) of title 18, United States Code, regarding the termination of a firearms dealer's license upon felony conviction. SEC. 7 grants the Director of the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms, and Explosives the authority to hire 50 additional personnel for inspections. SEC. 8 requires a report to Congress. The Director of the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms, and Explosives must provide biennial reports to Congress on the implementation of the Act, including resource needs and recommendations for ensuring firearms dealers comply with laws.
